A Marine Corps motto is "Improvise, Adapt and Overcome." Similarly, organizations that can quickly spot a challenge or opportunity faster than their competitors and respond effectively are likelier to deliver results, says Pamela Meyer, author of "The Agility Shift." She notes that Gap (GPS), the established clothing firm, is closing 175 stores in North America, while Zara, "its more agile counterpart, is thriving."
Bill Jensen, author of "Future Strong," adds that 40% of today's Fortune 500 companies will not exist in 10 years.
Tips on adapting your company and people to challenges:

 Deputize employees. Agile leaders, teams and organizations do not miss opportunities or slow their response time because "they are waiting on approval, or for someone with the correct job description to become available," Meyer emphasized. Effective executives hire and coach others to lead and respond to opportunities and challenges as they arise.

 Cross-train them. A solid way leaders at all levels become more agile, Meyer said, is to regularly seek out new opportunities and assignments: "UPS (UPS) and many other organizations have a recruit-from-within policy that is designed to ensure their leaders rotate through a wide range of experiences, from package delivery to leading a team in another country. Such experiences build competence and capacity to be effective when things don't go as planned."

 Get smarter. Meyer suggests creating a web of relationships and resources to respond to unexpected challenges. When they arise, "there is not always time to gather and analyze complex data," she said. "It is through their relational web that agile people tap their wider resources, knowledge and expertise to respond effectively. The time to discover and build this relational web is not in the midst of crisis, but through their day-to-day interactions."

Meyer adds that outfits of all sizes employ resources ranging from Google (GOOGL) groups to corporate social networks. These help the firms' people tap their relational web and access the skills, knowledge and talent they need.
 Recognize. When evaluating performance, value and reward agility and learning, as they go a long way toward reinforcing winning behavior, says Meyer.

 Jump outside comfort zones. To realize your firm's limitless capacity, "you must disrupt and reimagine those systems, long before best practices are established or all the risks have been mitigated — that takes leadership courage," Jensen said.

He notes that multinational management consulting giant Accenture (ACN) is eliminating its formal yearly review process for its 330,000 people, with CEO Pierre Nanterme making that leap so that his company can select the right person rather than solely measuring and evaluating people by numbers or statistics.

 Shoot for the moon. When your company has a problem or anticipates a challenge, apply what Google calls Moonshot Thinking, says Jensen. The title is gleaned from JFK's call to do the impossible and land a man on the moon.
Push your team to solve a massive problem. This could result in doing something cheaper and faster. Regardless of the outcome, your people could make a big difference.
 Learn from your workforce. Jensen suggests putting together a three-month task force to call out the top 10 things that should be blown up and changed by 2020.

His prediction: "Be prepared to embrace at least seven or eight of their top 10 recommendations."A Marine Corps motto is "Improvise, Adapt and Overcome." Shares of Accenture (ACN) edged up in early trading Thursday, though the tech consulting and outsourcing services provider's revenue outlook missed Wall Street expectations.

But Accenture's earnings per share minus items of $1 for its fiscal Q2 ended Feb. 28 was 3 cents better than the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, and was up 3 cents from the year-earlier quarter.
Revenue rose 4% to $7.1 billion, in line with Wall Street estimates.
The company expects revenue for the current quarter of $7.25 billion to $7.5 billion, up 1.3% to 4.8% from the year-ago period, but short of the $7.59 million analysts expected.
Accenture reported new bookings of $9.1 billion, up 14.6% from the year-ago period and up 21% from the prior quarter.

But Q2 consulting revenue dipped 1% from the year-earlier quarter. Company executives cautioned during a Thursday morning conference call with analysts that consulting bookings are converting at a slower-than-expected pace.
Still, executives framed Q2 results as a positive step toward a better second half of the fiscal year.

"We are pleased with our results for the second quarter, which were in line with our expectations," Accenture CEO Pierre Nanterme said on the call. "We remain well positioned to meet our outlook for the fiscal year."

Accenture also announced that its longtime chief financial officer, Pamela Craig, is retiring after 34 years with the company, including seven as CFO. David Rowland, Accenture's senior vice president of finance, will replace Craig when she departs on July 1, the company said.

Shares of Accenture were trading near 75.25 in the stock market today, and the stock is up 13% in 2013.Shares of Accenture (ACN) edged up in early trading Thursday, though the tech consulting and outsourcing services provider's revenue outlook missed Wall Street expectations.But Accenture's earnings per share minus items of $1 for its fiscal Q2 ended Feb. 28 was 3 cents better than the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, and was up 3 cents from the year-earlier quarter.Revenue rose 4% to $7.1 billion, in line with Wall Street estimates.The company expects revenue for the current quarter of $7.25 billion to $7.5 billion, up 1.3% to 4.8% from the year-ago period, but short of the $7.59 million analysts expected.Accenture reported new bookings of $9.1 billion, up 14.6% from the year-ago period and up 21% from the prior quarter.But Q2 consulting revenue dipped 1% from the year-earlier quarter. Faced with plunging oil prices that look to stay lower for longer, oilfield service giant Schlumberger (SLB) is slimming down, saying early Monday that it's agreed to sell its consulting business to Accenture (ACN). Financial terms of the deal weren't released. Following completion of the sale, all Schlumberger Business Consulting employees and its knowledge assets are expected to become part…

Epam Systems (EPAM) stock slipped in late trading Tuesday after the provider of outsourced software engineering and other IT services beat second-quarter revenue expectations but edged earnings views as it again faced foreign currency headwinds. Epam gets more than half its business from outside the U.S., so the strong U.S. dollar has weighed on its results — as it has…

Epam Systems (EPAM) might not be the best known stock in its industry group — not when that group includes tech heavyweights IBM (IBM), Accenture (ACN), Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) and Infosys (INFY) — but the provider of outsourced software engineering and other IT services takes a back seat to no one when it comes to consistently strong financial growth.With seven straight quarters of double-digit earnings and revenue gains, Epam has put in one of the best recent financial performances of any stock in IBD's Computer-Technology Services group.The company's 98 Composite Rating places it No. 2 in the group behind Cognizant, which boasts a 99 rating. Epam's stock is still trading near the all-time high of 75.89 it established on July 13. Epam stock closed Friday at 74.11, up 55% since the beginning of the year.Epam is expected to continue its double-digit growth streak when it reports second-quarter earnings after the close on Tuesday.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see Q2 earnings of 65 cents a share, up from 53 cents the prior year. Revenue is expected to rise 23% to $215.6 million.The strong growth numbers come despite some pretty significant headwinds for Epam.More than half of its business comes from outside the U.S., which means the strong U.S. dollar acts as a drag. In addition, the company does a lot of business in Ukraine, where political tensions with Russia are high. Meanwhile, it must also deal with rising inflation in the Commonwealth of Independent States, which includes Ukraine .

Accenture (ACN) reported better-than-expected fiscal Q3 earnings Thursday morning and raised its full-year guidance, sending the stock to a record high. Accenture reported revenue of $7.77 billion for the quarter ended May 31, up 0.4% from the year-earlier quarter and beating the consensus estimate of $7.54 billion among analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Earnings per share minus items rose 3%…

Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) is no stranger to the acquisitions game. The provider of information technology, consulting and business process outsourcing has made 16 buys since 2010. Its acquisition strategy has been to focus on geographic expansion and strengthening its industry knowledge or technological abilities, Cognizant President Gordon Coburn told IBD.

Until recently, most buys had been tuck-in acquisitions for $200 million or less. The exception came in November, when Cognizant closed on the $2.7 billion purchase of TriZetto, a privately held provider of health-care IT software that helps payers and providers work more efficiently together.

TriZetto could have wound up elsewhere, though few firms could have provided a healthier home. Only IBM (IBM), Accenture (ACN) and Infosys (INFY) enjoy larger market caps than Cognizant's $40.9 billion in IBD's Computer-Tech Services industry group, although Wipro (WIT) isn't far behind. But Cognizant is the only member of the industry group to earn the highest possible 99 Composite Rating.

At the time of the purchase, TriZetto software managed the health benefits of close to half the insured population of the U.S. and supported about a quarter of all U.S. care providers with more than 350 health plans.

TriZetto broadened the offerings of Cognizant's already fast-growing health-care segment, which provides health insurers, drug companies, biotech and other health-related businesses with services that address regulatory requirements, including compliance with the Affordable Care Act. At the time of the buy, Cognizant's health-care segment served more than 200 clients and accounted for about 26% of sales.
New Software Platforms
"TriZetto further strengthened our position in health care," Coburn told IBD. "TriZetto is the leading platform in health care administration.
"Most important, TriZetto brought us (software) platforms (complementing) technology and business process services" that Cognizant already offered.
Coburn says that with TriZetto in the mix, Cognizant is expanding from being a services provider to a combination of providing both services and platform products.

"That's a key component of our growth for the future in the health-care industry as well as other industries," he said, adding that Cognizant's strategy is to "buy, build and partner," using those platforms across various industries.
He says there will be "similar (growth) opportunities" in financial services and pharmaceuticals due to "changes in the regulatory environment, cost pressures and changing industry dynamics."
The financial services segment is Cognizant's biggest business, accounting for 41.8% of revenue in 2014. Its manufacturing, retail and logistics segment accounted for 20.4% of 2014 revenue.
An IBD Leaderboard stock, Cognizant has been on a long-running winning streak with 16 straight quarters of double-digit sales and earnings growth.

In the second quarter, adjusted earnings rose 20% to 79 cents a share, ahead of views. Revenue climbed 23% to $3.09 billion, also topping forecasts. Cognizant also raised its full-year 2015 earnings and revenue estimates for the second time this year.
Cognizant's stock rose 6.4% on Aug. 5, the day it reported second-quarter results. Its stock continues to hover near its all-time closing high of 68.44.

"This is a company where revenue growth is by far the main driver of its valuation," said Robert Baird's David Koning. Year-to-year "revenue growth in Q2 was the strongest in almost two years in both reported and organic and constant currency revenue."
Koning says the "backdrop" to support strong revenue growth is Cognizant's "good execution and willingness to invest in growth along with an industry backdrop that's still in a secular growth mode."
The industry's growth mode, he says, is being driven by companies' willingness to spend on offshore IT and certain vertical segments having "solid underlying growth."
The health care segment was the quarter's fastest grower, with a 39% rise in revenue.
TriZetto contributed about $171.1 million in sales and was one of the "drivers" of the big gain, said CEO Francisco D'Souza on the quarter's conference call.

Koning calculates that the offshore IT services industry has grown organic revenue on a constant currency basis about 10%-13% annually over the past few years, while Cognizant has grown around the mid-teens to 20%.
How has Cognizant kept up such a fast pace?

"When we went public in 1998, we made the decision to keep margins at between 19% and 20%, which was lower than many of our competitors at the time, and use that money to invest for the long term and deliver industry leading revenue growth," Coburn said. "We've continued to successfully execute on this strategy ever since."
He says Cognizant has invested in having "strong global delivery capabilities combined with deep industry knowledge and strong client relationships."

He added: "Our customers today have a dual mandate. They have to run their businesses better by becoming more efficient and effective. And they have to run their businesses different through digital (transformation) and how they interact with customers, employers and the supply chain. They do this by taking the money they've freed up from running better and investing it in running different."
Serving The Dual Mandate
"We're one of only a small number companies that can do both of those things at once," he said. "The core of our strategy is to serve clients on both sides of the dual mandate."
In the last year or so, he adds, Cognizant has seen "very strong demand" from customers in implementing digital transformation within their businesses.
"We've experienced explosive growth in this area," he said.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Cognizant's earnings to grow by 17% in 2015 to $3.03 a share. They see a 15% increase in 2016 and a 16% gain in 2017.

"The combination of all the changes related to the Affordable Care Act and the aging of the population creates a nice backdrop for growth in Cognizant's health-care segment, which represents about 30% of the company's revenue," said Koning. "We believe the backdrop is solid, but it's hard to predict when the ebbs and flows come."

Other highly rated members of IBD's Computer-Tech Services industry group include Epam Systems (EPAM) and CDW (CDW).Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) is no stranger to the acquisitions game. Tyler Technologies, which bills itself as America's largest provider of information management software and services to local governments, continues to bolster its position with an expanding portfolio of products to meet what it views as reliable demand from the public sector.
The Plano, Texas, firm's client base of over 13,000 local government offices spans all 50 states, as well as Canada, the Caribbean and the United Kingdom.

Following the 2007-08 financial crisis and the recession that accompanied it, local governments grappled with tax revenue shortfalls and budget struggles, forcing many to put off investments in new technology. In turn, Tyler (TYL) saw its growth curbed in 2010 and 2011.
As this happened, aging software and management systems — many of which dated to the late 1990s when governments last made upgrades en masse ahead of Y2K — grew outdated.
Once the economic recovery took hold, analysts say, rejuvenated local governments moved with haste to address pent-up demand for new technology, bolstering Tyler's fortunes.
Meeting Demand

Tyler Chief Financial Officer Brian Miller says the market has settled into a new normal now, one defined by solid demand from a broad customer base. The replacement cycle, coupled with increasing needs for advanced technology and Tyler's ability to sell more of its services to existing customers, creates a long runway for ongoing sales growth, he said in an interview.
"It's a very steady market with strong long-term opportunities," Miller said.

The company has generated double-digit gains in revenue for 14 straight quarters. Most recently, for the first quarter, it reported revenue of $135 million, up 20% from a year earlier. It posted net income of 59 cents per diluted share, an increase of 38%.
For Tyler's second-quarter report on July 22 after the stock market close, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect EPS of 61 cents, up 17%, on revenue of $142 million.
For the full year, Tyler has guided for revenue of $568 million to $575 million, with EPS of $2.46 to $2.54.
The analyst consensus is for a little under $574 million in revenue and $2.52 EPS.

Tyler is a part of IBD's Computer-Tech Services industry group. The biggest names in the group by market cap are IBM (IBM), Accenture (ACN) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH), but Tyler is highest-ranked by Composite Rating, with a 98 out of a possible 99 from IBD.

Tyler's managerial offerings include enterprise resource planning (ERP) for cities, counties and schools — everything from electronic records management to payroll processing — as well as software and systems that automate property assessments.
Revved Up In The Downturn
Miller says the company invested in research and development in the aftermath of the recession, pushing for innovation when most competitors pulled back on that front.

It has developed faster, more comprehensive and easier-to-integrate systems that are of increasing appeal to local governments that need to replace systems and want to do so with technology that can make them more efficient.
Miller says that as Tyler invested in R&D, many of its smaller competitors who "went the opposite direction" have since lost relevancy.

Miller adds that two-thirds of the local government ERP systems needing to be replaced in the near future were bought from companies that no longer compete with Tyler — creating fertile ground for new business.
Another big advantage for Tyler, analysts say, is that it operates in multiple areas of the local government arena, while smaller players tend to be less diverse.
This lets Tyler provide more comprehensive services at competitive rates and sell more of its offerings to each customer.
"They've really become the standout," Benchmark Co. analyst Mark Schappel told IBD, adding that smaller competitors are "less and less meaningful. Tyler is in the driver's seat."
Miller also credits Tyler's "evergreen" program for its software.

Under a systems support or subscription agreement with a customer, he says, the client pays small annual maintenance costs, as opposed to dealing with large periodic licensing fees, and in exchange gets regular software updates to stay current.

Tyler this year introduced a companion offering, its EverGuide initiative for services and consulting. This should further boost customers' "upsell likelihood," William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho said in a research report.

Tyler competes with industry stalwarts such as SAP (SAP) and Oracle (ORCL). Miller says that Tyler often wins business over its larger rivals because customers appreciate its focus solely on the public sector —local governments in particular.
The Tyler staffers responsible for integrating new technology for customers "know that business backward and forward," he said.
Winning Contracts

Miller says that Tyler has been consistently posting overall win rates of 60% or better — meaning it beats out the competition at least 60% of the time on the business it goes after — and that is 10% better than prior to the recession. Tyler is generating even higher win rates in certain businesses.

The company's courts-and-justice operation is a key example of this, Miller says. Its software helps administrators manage jails, aids police and prosecutors in tracking cases, and connects the three entities to provide efficient case management and records updates.

Tyler's Odyssey court-case management system, an electronic filing service, processes fines and generates court documents among other tasks, reducing staffing hours and paper costs for local governments, the company says.
Tyler's win rate is "north of 85%" in the courts-and-justice business, Miller said. "We are winning virtually every meaningful deal in that space."
Business has been particularly robust in California. Miller notes that a drawn-out effort to develop a statewide court system there was ultimately scrapped two years ago.
It left counties, which had put their own systems in limbo in anticipation of moving under a state umbrella, to hastily pursue upgrades.
"That created an accelerated demand," he said. "A lot of the counties had very urgent needs to replace systems."
Courting California

Of 58 counties in California, 28 have bought new systems, and Tyler has won 25 of those deals, Miller says. "I think we've won the last 18 in a row. We clearly have been very, very successful in that marketplace," he said.
Its clients range from the smallest counties all the way up to the largest, Los Angeles County.
The L.A. County contract was valued at $32 million, Miller says.
"In our view," analyst Ho wrote, "the courts-and-justice business continues to be a source of significant opportunity for the company."

Tyler's growth plans could include acquisitions, Miller says, adding that the company is "very disciplined" on pricing. With no debt on its balance sheet and strong cash flow, he says, it has its eyes open for attractive opportunities.

He points to its acquisition of Brazos Technology in May as a good example. Brazos makes handheld electronic devices for police officers to record traffic tickets and accident information. Brazos had generated annual revenue under $10 million. But by pairing its devices with Tyler's broader offerings and larger client base, Miller says, Tyler can boost those sales.

He adds that Tyler in recent years has sought out targets of Brazos' size, largely to fill gaps in its service, and has the wherewithal to do larger deals too. That said, Tyler is so confident in its organic growth prospects that it feels no pressure to move urgently on the deal front.

Stocks finished lower as talks again failed to bring an agreement on Greek debt while economic data were generally upbeat Thursday.
The Nasdaq slipped 0.2%, the S&P; 500 fell 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average closed down 0.4%. Preliminary numbers showed volume mixed, up on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq exchange.
In economic news, personal income and consumer spending topped forecasts. Spending jumped 0.9% for the biggest gain in more than five years.

Weekly jobless claims inched higher but came in below the consensus forecast. The four-week average edged lower as well. But Markit's flash service-sector PMI dipped to 54.8 in June from 56.2 in May and missed expectations.

Heath care stocks were the big winners in the stock market today, particularly hospitals and managed care providers. The Supreme Court ruled favorably Thursday regarding the legality of ObamaCare federal tax subsidies.
From the hospital group, HCA Holdings (HCA), Community Health Systems (CYH), LifePoint Health (LPNT) and Universal Health Services (UHS) all surged to record highs in heavy trade.

TeamHealth Holdings (TMH), a provider of outsourced physician staffing for hospitals, jumped 6% and broke out past a 63.99 buy point of a flat base. TeamHealth is part of the health care commercial services group along with recent IPO HealthEquity (HQY), which also hit a new high. Both stocks have a 96 Composite Rating.

Earnings news from Accenture (ACN) sent the stock to a record high. Shares added close to 2% in heavy trading as earnings and revenue topped estimates. Accenture stock is in a buy range past a 98.05 flat-base buy point.

On the downside, Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) fell nearly 2% in heavy trade as its fiscal Q1 results failed to impress investors. Earnings came up just short of expectations, while sales matched views. Stocks held on tightly to small gains midday Thursday. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 added 0.1% each, while the Dow Jones industrial average clung to a fractional gain. Volume was tracking mixed in the stock market today, higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq exchange.
Hospitals, managed care and outpatient care industries were top performers after Thursday's Supreme Court ruling upheld the legality of subsidies under the Affordable Care Act.

Hospital operator Community Health Systems (CYH) surged 13% and broke out past a 57.82 consolidation buy point. Volume was tracking at more than 10 times normal pace. Fellow operator HCA Holdings (HCA) also jumped 9% on the news.

Disney (DIS) shares shot to a new high on news the media giant is hiking its dividend by 15%. The company will now make shareholder payouts twice a year rather than annually. Disney stock is just past a 113.40 flat-base buy point after breaking out a week ago.

Earnings news from Accenture (ACN) sent the stock to a record high. Shares added more than 2% in heavy trading as earnings and revenue topped analyst consensus estimates. Accenture stock is in a buy range past a 98.05 flat-base buy point.

On the downside, Methode Electronics (MEI) cratered 30% after reporting mixed fiscal Q4 results and issuing a weak outlook. Shares cut through the 40-week moving average and hit a 52-week low. Methode Electronics had triggered a sell signal in the prior week by closing below the 10-week moving average line in heavy volume.Stocks held on tightly to small gains midday Thursday. Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) will have a lot to prove when it reports its fiscal second-quarter earnings after the market close Thursday.The computer products giant aims to rebound from its first-quarter earnings report, which included revenue that fell short of analyst estimates. Sales fell or were flat across all six of HP's business sectors. HP stock tumbled nearly 10% on Feb. 25, the day following its earnings report, to a seven-month low. HP stock is down more than 15% this year.Prior to Q1, HP had been building a groundswell of support from investors as the company gets closer to splitting into two separate companies, with PCs and printers in one company and enterprise services, equipment and software in the other. The split is expected to occur in October.HP is also amid a five-year restructuring plan launched in May 2012 aimed at placing more emphasis on emerging growth areas, including the cloud and security, as PC and printer growth slows.HP is in a quandary by operating in a difficult PC and printer market while trying to compete with rivals such as Accenture (ACN) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) in the enterprise services and equipment businesses, says Brian White, an analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald. He rates HP stock a hold."PCs is obviously a very difficult business," White told IBD. "though they did pretty well last year. And they do a good job in printing, but it's kind of a secular, declining business."They are not really great at the enterprise side. In services, they kind of stubbed their own toe and weren't investing in the right places and making promises (to customers) that they didn't deliver on... . I don't think there is anything to look at in services and say that is a great growing business for them."EPS, Sales Both Seen FallingThis month, Cisco reported stronger-than-expected April-quarter earnings that included growth in its data center enterprise business.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect HP to report earnings per share minus items of 85 cents, down 3.4% from the year-earlier quarter. That would be its first EPS decline in six quarters.Revenue is expected to fall 6% to $25.65 billion, which would be its worst showing in the past seven quarters.For the current quarter, analysts expect EPS to fall 2.2% to 87 cents and revenue to fall 6.1% to $25.88 billion.HP's coming split should boost its shares, Sherri Scribner, an analyst for Deutsche Bank, said in a May 14 research report. She has a buy rating on HP stock."We view HP as well positioned to benefit from growth in emerging segments like Big Data and converged infrastructure, and expect further operating margin improvements in HP's enterprise business," she wrote. "With shares not currently reflecting HP's strong industry position, growth opportunities and operating margin expansion, we view current valuations as attractive and the stock remains one of our top picks for 2015."While many investors have focused on near-term negative synergies of the deal, we believe the split will create positive synergies for the company, which should offset any negative synergies over the longer term."

Global consulting firm Accenture (ACN) is holding just below a recent buy point ahead of its fiscal Q2 earnings report next week. The stock broke out past a 91.54 buy point from a shallow cup-with-handle pattern on March 5. Volume, though, was only 26% above average. Shares hit a new all-time high that day, but were not able to follow through.
The stock fell as much as 6% below the buy point, nearly triggering a sell signal. Shares have since recovered, though, retaking the 50-day line and approaching the old high.
Accenture provides consulting, technology and outsourcing services in more than 120 countries across the globe. It has offices in 200 cities and employs more than 300,000 people.

It will report fiscal second-quarter results before the open on Thursday. Analysts expect earnings per share of 1.07, up 4%, on a 4% gain in revenues. It would be the slowest earnings and sales gains in four quarters. Still, it would mark the 10th straight quarter of positive year-over-year growth in both sales and earnings.
Accenture pays a semi-annual dividend with a current yield of 2.3%. IBD calculates an annual dividend growth rate of 33%.

It is part of the highly rated Computer-Tech Services industry group. With an 82 Composite Rating it ranks near the middle of the 43-stock group. Group leaders by Composite Rating include Epam Systems (EPAM), Tyler Technologies (TYL) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH).
Fewer than half of the stocks in the group pay a dividend, however, and Accenture sports the highest yield among stocks with at least a 50 Composite Rating.

Cognizant Technology Solutions endured a weak IT spending environment, health care industry changes and other issues to post first-quarter sales that just met views and per-share profit 7 cents better than expected.The global information technology consulting and outsourcing firm's outlook mirrored its Q1 with revenue slightly below views and a per-share profit 4 cents ahead of views. But investors weren't satisfied. Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) stock fell 4.4% to 47.02 on the news Wednesday.Cognizant's results followed mixed results from two rivals. Infosys (INFY) reported revenue slightly below estimates while its per-share profit arrived just above views for its fourth quarter. Accenture's (ACN) fiscal Q2 results fell short of analyst estimates on the top and bottom lines.Cognizant's results still look promising against the austere IT spending backdrop and when compared against recent year-over-year quarterly growth rates of 1% for Accenture and 12% for Infosys, Susquehanna Financial Group analyst Jamie Friedman said."It's tough out there in IT and IT services," he said. "This is actually better than expected. Pretty much everyone in this group has been missing their numbers and they have been missing at a much lower growth rate."During a conference call, Cognizant President Gordon Coburn said several issues conspired to limit revenue growth in Q1. They included the federal Affordable Care Act, aka ObamaCare; leadership changes at some health care company customers; and heavy storm activity in North America in the early part of year, he said."There was no single cause for these headwinds," he said. "It was a confluence of several factors."Investors could be jumping the gun by dumping shares, Janney Montgomery Scott analyst Joseph Foresi says."It's important to keep in mind (that) March is typically the seasonally slow quarter because IT budgets are specifically set for that particular quarter," he said. "Secondly, discretionary spending (by customers) was off to a better start this year than last year, which means the environment is pretty good."The slight miss on the revenue outlook for Q2 also shouldn't be too alarming, Foresi says."The guide was not as exciting as people had wanted but I think the fundamentals are still very much in place," he said.In the quarter ended March 31, Cognizant reported a per-share profit of 62 cents, minus items, up 21.5% vs. 51 cents in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 55 cents.Revenue rose 20% to $2.42 billion, matching views.For the current quarter, the company expects a per-share profit, ex items, of 62 cents vs. 50 cents in the year-earlier period. Analysts were modeling for 58 cents.

A survey says U.S. employees are eager to take an entrepreneurial approach to their jobs. But most believe their companies don't do enough to support and reward their efforts to generate ideas.

Fifty-two percent of 800 corporate staffers and managers surveyed by Accenture (ACN) say they've pursued an entrepreneurial idea inside their company. However, only 20% believe their employers offer enough support for developing new ideas.

Although 53% say their companies are better at backing entrepreneurism than they were five years ago, many cite obstacles. Thirty-six percent say the biggest hurdle is their current job keeping them too busy to pursue new ideas, and 20% blame lack of management support. Thirteen percent say a lack of incentives for generating entrepreneurial ideas is a major roadblock.

More than half, or 53%, also say their company doesn't support ideas from all levels of the workforce and 77% say new ideas are rewarded only when they're used and proven to work.A survey says U.S. employees are eager to take an entrepreneurial approach to their jobs. But most believe their companies don't do enough to support and reward their efforts to generate ideas.Fifty-two percent of 800 corporate staffers and managers surveyed by Accenture (ACN) say they've pursued an entrepreneurial idea inside their company. Accenture (ACN) stock was up more than 4% in midday trading Thursday after the company posted quarterly earnings that beat views and raised the full-year profit forecast.

The company is one of the largest providers of tech consulting and business process outsourcing services. Increased demand for outsourcing services in the quarter helped to offset a drop in its consulting business.
Accenture early Thursday reported earnings per share minus items of $1.15, up 8.5% from the year-earlier quarter and 5 cents above estimates, for its fiscal first quarter ended Nov. 30.
Revenue rose 2% to $7.36 billion and topped the consensus estimate of $7.25 billion by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.
Revenue from consulting services fell 1% to $3.94 billion, but outsourcing revenue rose 5% to $3.42 billion.
Accenture stock was near 79 in midday trading in the stock market today.
The company reported $8.7 billion in new bookings, almost event split between consulting and outsourcing.

"We were pleased with our ability to continue driving profitable growth in a global economic environment that remains challenging," said Accenture CEO Pierre Nanterme said in the company's earnings release. "We continue to invest in differentiated services and evolve our operating model to capture new growth opportunities across all dimensions of our business, especially in digital and transformation."
For the current quarter, Accenture expects revenue of $6.95 billion to $7.25 billion, shy of the analyst consensus estimate of $7.28 billion.
But Accenture raised its profit forecast for its fiscal 2014 by 2 cents, to $4.44 to $4.56. The consensus estimate is $4.47.
Accenture maintained projections for revenue to increase 2% to 6%.

Shares of Accenture (ACN) rose 1% Tuesday morning after the leading global consulting and outsourcing firm said it completed its acquisition of Prion Group, a consulting and systems integrator that specializes in Siemens product lifecycle management software.
Accenture announced its intent to acquire Prion on Aug. 12. Terms were not disclosed.

Prion's product lifecycle management software can be applied to several manufacturing sectors including industrial equipment, automotive, consumer goods, aerospace and defense, said Eric Schaeffer, Accenture's senior managing director in a company release.

"The acquisition of Prion Group will enable Accenture to help our clients increase the return on investment in PLM by accelerating and optimizing their implementations, particularly in Europe and North America," he said.
Accenture could use a boost after its Q4 earnings report.

Shares of Accenture (ACN) fell a fraction early Thursday after the leading global technology consulting and outsourcing firm said it has agreed to acquire Procurian, a privately held U.S.-based provider of business process outsourcing for $375 million in cash.
Procurian is a unit of ICG Group (ICGE), a company that acquires and builds Internet software and services companies. Shares of ICG jumped by about 10% Thursday.
The acquisition is expected to close by the end of the calendar year.
The deal comes two days after Accenture completed its acquisition of the Prion Group for an undisclosed sum.

Acquiring Procurian will strengthen Accenture's abilities in procurement business process outsourcing in a wide range of industries including manufacturing, consumer goods, technology and financial services while adding key analytics capabilities and related technology assets, Mike Savino, Accenture's group chief executive for business process outsourcing, said in a company release.

"The addition of Procurian's deep strategic sourcing category expertise, advanced analytics capabilities and delivery resources will complement and scale our already significant sourcing and procurement business services," he said.

When you build trust into the fabric of your organization, people can depend on others and are reliable enough for their peers to count on them. A good firm needs both, says Charlie Green, founder and president of Trusted Advisor Associates, a West Orange, N.J.-based training and leadership development firm. Here's why and how to achieve that.

• Speed it up. Things go faster and costs fall when you have a workplace built on trust, Green says. When you trust your customer, and vice versa, you can make deals faster. Employees don't have to check up on each other constantly, either. And customers stay with you. "The economics of customer retention are huge," he told IBD. "They're bigger than being the low-cost producer."
• Get creative. A trusting environment is a breeding ground for innovation. People share ideas only with others they can rely on, underscores Green. That collaboration leads to new approaches.
• Display. Leaders must show they can be trusted if they want others to rely on fellow employees. Follow through on commitments and be consistent and transparent.

"If the leader isn't accountable, the employees won't be, and it trickles on through," said Bette Price, CEO of Dallas-based leadership consulting firm Price Group. "But if I can trust my supervisor, I'll be more committed to not letting that supervisor down."

• Recruit. Trust is a huge factor for young workers such as millennials, Price says. If you have it, they'll come to work for you. They tend to want to trust their supervisor and to be trusted. The key is to avoid overseeing every little move an employee makes. "If I'm being micromanaged, it means you don't trust me," Price said.

• Focus on others. If you make decisions based on what's best for the customer or the other employees, you'll win their trust, Green says. One tech company rep told a client it didn't need an expensive overhaul, just a low-cost product. He looked past the big commission to help the client.
"The customer says, 'I believe him, because why would he give up the sale?'" Green said. "That's enormously credibility-building."

• Communicate. Some managers don't mean to seem distrustful, but come across that way. Price worked with one firm where the employees complained that the manager constantly asked questions about how they did their jobs. It made them feel that he didn't trust them. It turned out he asked simply so he could explain their jobs to higher-ups.
"If he completely communicated that, it would put it in a whole different context," Price said.
• Talk about it. Price knows one leader who garnered trust by meeting once a month with employees. They could ask anything, and he answered as much as he could.
"That establishes that credibility of trust," she said.
• Set a clear path. Green watched a meeting that Bill Green, then-CEO of consulting firm Accenture (ACN) and no relation to Charlie, conducted with his firm's senior leaders.
One asked if global colleagues would be compensated for doing things the proper way for clients.
The CEO made his priorities obvious: Values come before cash incentives.

• Start strong. The best leaders go into a situation assuming they can trust people, Price says. That builds a culture of honesty and accountability. They keep trusting unless people prove otherwise. "But if you're betrayed, that bank account drains quickly," she said. "And it's real hard to build it back up again."When you build trust into the fabric of your organization, people can depend on others and are reliable enough for their peers to count on them. A good firm needs both, says Charlie Green, founder and president of Trusted Advisor Associates, a West Orange, N.J.-based training and leadership development firm. Here's why and how to achieve that.• Speed it up. Things go faster and costs fall when you have a workplace built on trust, Green says. When you trust your customer, and vice versa, you can make deals faster. Employees don't have to check up on each other constantly, either. And customers stay with you. "The economics of customer retention are huge," he told IBD. "They're bigger than being the low-cost producer."• Get creative. A trusting environment is a breeding ground for innovation. People share ideas only with others they can rely on, underscores Green. That collaboration leads to new approaches.• Display. Follow through on commitments and be consistent and transparent."If the leader isn't accountable, the employees won't be, and it trickles on through," said Bette Price, CEO of Dallas-based leadership consulting firm Price Group. "But if I can trust my supervisor, I'll be more committed to not letting that supervisor down."• Recruit. Trust is a huge factor for young workers such as millennials, Price says. If you have it, they'll come to work for you. They tend to want to trust their supervisor and to be trusted. The key is to avoid overseeing every little move an employee makes. "If I'm being micromanaged, it means you don't trust me," Price said.• Focus on others. Accenture (ACN) stock fell nearly 4% in morning trading Friday, one day after the big technology consulting and outsourcing services company's earnings and outlook missed Wall Street expectations, as an executive cited a "lower growth" cycle.
For its fiscal Q4 ended Aug. 31, Accenture reported per-share profit minus items, of $1.01, which missed views by a penny, vs. 88 cents in the year-earlier period.
Revenue rose 4% to $7.1 billion, edging views by $200,000.
For its first quarter, Accenture expects revenue of $7 billion and $7.3 billion, up 2.8% to 4.2%, below views of $7.39 billion.
During a conference call late Thursday with analysts, Accenture CEO Pierre Nanterme said the company continues to be challenged by a tough macroeconomy.

"At a time where volatility and uncertainty are still the name of the game, we continue to focus on driving our own competitiveness, applying rigor and discipline across the board to increase our efficiency and expand our margins," he said. "And this is giving us the capacity to invest in the business to continue to capture new ways of growth."
But the company's growth path doesn't appear to be getting easier, David Rowland, Accenture's chief financial officer, said on the call.

"For the past four to five quarters, it's clear that our addressable market has been in a cycle of lower growth and this has clearly impacted our growth," he said. "As we look forward, we think it's likely that our overall market conditions won't change much in the near term. In other words, it will be more of the same."
Accenture stock, which hit an all-time high of 84.22 in May, is trading near 73 in the stock marketFriday.

"As we look forward, we think it's likely that our overall market conditions won't change much in the near term. In other words, it will be more of the same."Accenture stock, which hit an all-time high of 84.22 in May, is trading near 73 in the stock marketFriday.On Monday, Linux leader Red Hat (RHT) also gave a disappointing outlook, in part due to macroeconomic concerns focused on Europe, as IBD reported.

A company that is raising its dividend certainly has its shareholders in mind. So which companies today have been raising them the fastest over the past three to five years?

IBD scoured its Dividend Leaders Screen (see a partial list on this page) to find the firms that are showing at least double-digit growth in the cash payout. Twenty-nine make the cut. The average long-term increase is 26%.

Imagine owning a stock that not only has excellent earnings stability (which is critical for dividends) and sound fundamentals but also has the potential for decent capital appreciation and a bigger dividend. For an income investor, it's the best of all worlds.

Novartis (NVS) heads the list. IBD calculates that the Swiss ethical drug giant has grown its dividend by 60% over the past three to five years. The annualized dividend is $2.39 a share, equivalent to a 2.3% yield, which beats the S&P 500's 1.87% yield.
Novartis also boasts a three-year Earnings Stability Factor of 2 on a scale of zero (highly stable) to 99 (highly volatile).
In 2014, Novartis earned $5.23 a share on revenue of $58 billion, flat vs. a year ago.
Wells Fargo (WFC) ranks second in IBD's Dividend Leaders with a 57% dividend growth rate. The annualized cash dividend is $1.40 a share, yielding 2.6%.

The bank's business is centered on the U.S. consumer, mortgage and commercial markets. So it takes somewhat less of a hit on the income statement when overseas economies sour. The stock has recently rallied back above the key 50-day moving average. Upside resistance lingers near the 55 price level.

Media giant Gannett (GCI) sports the third-best dividend growth at 56% and is followed by CME Group (CME) at 49% and U.S. Bancorp (USB) (47%). Rounding out the top 10 are PNC Financial Services (PNC) (44%), Cisco Systems (CSCO) (38%), Accenture (ACN) (33%) and Quest Diagnostics (DGX) (33%). ACE Limited (ACE) and Lorillard (LO) tie for 10th at 30% growth.A company that is raising its dividend certainly has its shareholders in mind. Accenture's revenue ascended in its fiscal fourth quarter, but investors focused on the company's Q4 earnings miss and lower-than-expected sales outlook for the current quarter.The global management consulting, technology and outsourcing service company announced its fourth-quarter numbers before the market opened Wednesday, results that showed its first double-digit revenue growth in more than two years.Accenture's (ACN) Q4 revenue beat Wall Street's estimates, but that was tempered by earnings per share that were short of views.The company's revenue estimate range for the current quarter was also on the light side of estimates.The stock rose 0.8% to 80.20.The fact that Accenture reported double-digit revenue growth across four of its biggest operating groups and encouraging year-over-year gains in the U.S. and Europe seems to indicate the company is on the right track, says James Friedman, an analyst for Susquehanna Financial Group. He has a buy rating on the company."This is the fastest growth the company has had in 2-1/2 years," he told IBD, noting that the company posted its first double-digit, year-over-year quarterly growth since early 2012. "This is a large company that is suggesting a pattern of acceleration."Joseph Foresi, an analyst for Janney Montgomery Scott, was more cautious in his assessment of the quarter. He also has a buy rating on the company."The growth was relatively steady across most service verticals and geographies," he told IBD. "The underlying business appears stable; that was evident in the execution in the quarter."For the quarter ended Aug. 31, Accenture reported earnings per share minus items of $1.08, up 7% from the same period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected $1.10. Revenue climbed 10% to $7.78 billion. Wall Street was looking for sales of $7.62 billion, or growth of 7%.For the year, Accenture reported earnings per share of $4.52, up nearly 8% but a penny short of views. Revenue climbed 5% to $30 billion, ahead of estimates of $29.8 billion, or growth of 4.4%.For the current quarter, Accenture said it expects revenue of $7.55 billion to $7.80 billion, or growth of 2.7% to 6%. Analysts were expecting $7.8 billion in sales. For the full year, Accenture expects earnings per share of $4.74 to $4.88, up 4.8% to 7.9%.While analysts expect $4.91, Friedman says investors shouldn't read too much into the company's light forecast."They do have a pattern of starting conservative," he said.Pierre Nanterme, Accenture's chief executive, was upbeat about the company's performance and prospects during the company's conference call with analysts early Wednesday. "Our performance for the fiscal year, especially ... in the fourth quarter and the second half of the year demonstrates that we are executing the right growth strategy," he said. "We are providing relevant and highly differentiated services that are clearly resonating with the needs of our clients, and we are gaining market share even in an environment that continues to be very demanding and highly competitive."In the quarter, Accenture's consulting revenue grew 6% to $4 billion, while outsourcing revenue climbed 15% to $3.8 billion.Accenture's new bookings for its consulting business were $3.9 billion, 47% of total bookings, while outsourcing accounted for $4.4 billion, or 53%.Revenue from the company's communications, media and technology operating group jumped 14% to $1.58 billion.Financial services climbed 10% to $1.67 billion. The health and public service business also grew 10%, to $1.29 billion. The firm's products unit rose 14% to $1.93 billion.Growth in Accenture's resource group was flat at $1.29 billion.On the regional front, Accenture's Q4 revenue from the Americas increased 9% to $3.77 billion, while the $3 billion in Europe, the Middle East and Africa marked a 14% jump.Revenue from the Asia-Pacific region grew 3% to $982 million.One key to Accenture's growth resurgence is the company's offering of more fast-growing tech services such as mobile applications, data analytics software and interactive applications, Friedman says."Accenture is the first large service company that is actually pivoting to the next generation of computing," he said. "Accenture sells a lot of different stuff than they did two years ago, and that new stuff has a much better budget trajectory; that is why the growth is back."

Shares of Accenture (ACN), a leading tech services and consulting firm, were up more than 6% — an all-time high — in early afternoon trading Friday, after the company late Thursday reported fiscal Q4 sales and bookings that beat Wall Street expectations.
But the company's per-share profit minus items fell 3% to 88 cents, just meeting the views of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Here was IBD's earnings story.

Analysts focused on Accenture's bookings of $9.2 billion, up 9.5% from $8.4 billion in the year-earlier quarter, and the company's projected earnings for the fiscal year of $4.22 to $4.30 a share, vs. analyst views of $4.20. The company's revenue outlook also beat analyst expectations, Moshe Katri, an analyst for Cowen & Co., wrote in a research note Friday.
But Katri said the bookings growth was clearly the high point of the quarter.

"The company attributed booking strength to a combination of its strong/deep client relationships (60% of deals are sole sourced, up from 50% in the past), service mix relevance and solid competitive wins," he wrote. "The company indicated that one or two contracts were signed earlier than expected, raising questions on whether clients could be expediting spending decisions ahead of the November elections."Shares of Accenture (ACN), a leading tech services and consulting firm, were up more than 6% — an all-time high — in early afternoon trading Friday, after the company late Thursday reported fiscal Q4 sales and bookings that beat Wall Street expectations.But the company's per-share profit minus items fell 3% to 88 cents, just meeting the views of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. The company's revenue outlook also beat analyst expectations, Moshe Katri, an analyst for Cowen & Co., wrote in a research note Friday.But Katri said the bookings growth was clearly the high point of the quarter."The company attributed booking strength to a combination of its strong/deep client relationships (60% of deals are sole sourced, up from 50% in the past), service mix relevance and solid competitive wins," he wrote. "The company indicated that one or two contracts were signed earlier than expected, raising questions on whether clients could be expediting spending decisions ahead of the November elections."

Shares of Accenture (ACN), a leading global outsourcing and technology consulting services company, were up 5.2% in afternoon trading Friday after the company's earnings results released late Thursday beat expectations.Accenture reported a profit of $1.03, 4 cents better than analysts' views of 99 cents and up 11% from 93 cents in the year-ago period.Revenue rose 6% to $7.2 billion.For the current quarter, Accenture said it expected revenue of $6.6 billion to $6.85 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had been expecting $6.99 billion, a consensus forecast lowered to $6.79 billion on Friday.NCP Northland Capital Partners analyst Ralph Garcea characterized Accenture's Q3 as "a robust quarter."The results indicate continued demand for Accenture's services, even in a rocky economy, wrote Garcea in a research note published Friday."Accenture's overall results and guidance (are) a positive indicator given the current macro economic picture in Europe and the rest of the world," Garcea wrote. "We believe that enterprises continue to evolve corporate IT strategies, focusing on IT outsourcing strategies with a view to savings longer term, while keeping IT spending at or above the levels seen in previous years to improve the competitiveness."
Accenture (ACN) is giving its product life cycle management business a boost.

The technology consulting and outsourcing company on Monday said it would acquire Prion Group, a privately held consulting and systems integrator based in Stuttgart, Germany, that specializes in Siemens product life cycle management software deployments.
Terms weren't disclosed.

Accenture expects the acquisition will help strengthen its ability to help its clients deliver products to their customers faster and more efficiently, Koen Deryckere, an Accenture senior managing director, said in the company's announcement.

"With manufacturing companies spending as much as 25% of their revenue on innovation and product development, product life cycle management can help them avoid investments in products that are either late to market or don't fully address customer requirements," he said. "The combination of Prion Group's product life cycle management specialist skills and Accenture's industrialized delivery methodologies and global scale will help clients tackle the fragmented system and process landscape in the product development space, which many companies face today."

Accenture shares were down a fraction in midday trading in the stock marketMonday, to 73. Shares touched an all-time high of 84.22 on May 22 but fell more than 10% in late June after the company posted revenue for the quarter ended May 31 that lagged Wall Street expectations, on lower-than-expected consulting revenue. Francisco D'Souza is used to surfing the big waves of change.He was born in Nairobi, Kenya; grew up in 10 other countries, including Panama and Congo; and had to learn languages just to survive in school.During the boom of the late 1990s, he helped launch the tech service firm Cognizant (CTSH), was its North American director through the tech crash of the early 2000s and became CEO in January 2007.Despite the recession that started late that year, D'Souza has overseen revenue growth from $1.4 billion to 2012's $7.4 billion while providing everything from software system integration to high-tech strategic consulting.Arvind Ramnani of BNP Paribas predicts that Cognizant's revenue will bulge to $8.9 billion in 2013 and $10.3 billion in 2014.Meanwhile, Cognizant's stock has rocketed 525% since late 2008."I think the key to success in the business world today is to learn how to adapt rapidly," D'Souza, 45, told IBD.D'Souza is the son of an Indian diplomat, which meant the family moved to a different country every few years. His parents put their children in native schools instead of the international ones, favored by many foreigners, that minimized contact with the locals.Worldly"We learned to thrive in a flat world long before the term became in vogue," said D'Souza. "My multicultural experience had a decisive impact on the way we consciously built Cognizant to serve a global marketplace."His father bought him a computer when he was 13.Frank taught himself programming and in three years developed software to manage the inventory of a division of the Trinidad army.At 18 he worked as a teller in an international bank in Hong Kong during the day and went to the University of East Asia in Macau at night. The bank was using a punch-card system that was no longer supported by the vendor, so he helped implement a software program.A year later he worked with a small startup to invent a mass fax machine that could send out advertising for products and daily stock quotes, in the process learning the basics of entrepreneurship.After earning a bachelor's degree in business in 1991, D'Souza entered the MBA program at Pittsburgh's Carnegie Mellon University. He had to take a job on campus to pay the bills, so he pulled all-nighters before tests and took power naps between classes.He dreamed of starting a tech company, but had no green card to let him stay in America as an entrepreneur. After graduation in 1992, he joined credit information provider Dun & Bradstreet (DNB) and went to Germany. The next year, he heard D&B wanted to focus on emerging markets, so he volunteered to help create a software service arm in Chennai, India.Originally called DBSS and servicing D&B's in-house needs, the unit was spun off as Cognizant in 1996 and the next year moved to Teaneck, N.J. It went public in 1998.Meanwhile, D'Souza got his green card, and from 1997 to 2003 he directed North American operations and business development, getting through the dot-com bust by doing information technology projects that bigger firms ignored."One day, I might be out selling to prospective clients; the next, I could be figuring out how to process our payroll," he said.D'Souza's lesson is that marketing experience can be a great plus to help reach your career goals, no matter what they are. He served as chief operating officer from December 2003 to December 2006 before becoming CEO at 38.Cognizant rolled onto Fortune's "100 Fastest-Growing Companies" list from 2003 to 2012 and became one of the Fortune 500 in 2011.While it has big-name allies such as Microsoft (MSFT), Oracle (ORCL) and SAS, Cognizant faces competition from giants such as IBM (IBM), Accenture (ACN) and Hewlett-Packard (HPQ).Cognizant does general business and management consulting, which can range from business process re-engineering to mergers-and-acquisitions program management. Its sweet spot is to address points where technology and operations intersect, such as integrating complex systems and implementing new applications.Cognizant operates in over 40 countries, but D'Souza cautions that keeping costs low for clients should not be the sole value when it comes to outsourcing."Clients today need to address a dual mandate — driving costs down in their core business, while simultaneously innovating and transforming their business by leveraging the new SMAC stack," D'Souza said, referring to social mobility, data analytics and cloud service. "With structural shifts in economy, business and technology, enterprises are forced to re-examine how they operate, moving from merely incremental levels of performance efficiency to building new digital business capabilities. In this context, not only do they need to run better; they need to run different."GrowthCognizant has convinced so many C-level executives that it can do a superior job at reasonable prices while driving their innovation agenda that its client list has grown from 400 to 1,100 under D'Souza.His firm currently has more than 166,000 employees globally."It has also doubled revenue per client over the past five years," wrote Ramnani. "The trend is reflective of the value that Cognizant provides to its clients in an environment where they were consolidating their vendor relationships."Cognizant's inroads into some industries are nothing short of stunning. Its customers include 27 of the top 30 global pharmaceutical companies, nine of the 10 leading biotechs, 12 of the biggest medical device makers, four of five online powerhouses, as well as six of the top 10 North American financial institutions and all top 10 in Europe.Part of the company's formula for gaining loyalty is deep experience with its Two-in-a-Box approach. One part of the team is a Cognizant business expert who has over 15 years' experience in that industry and works at the client's site. That specialist works with an IT specialist who has the same level of experience implementing projects.When the recession hit in late 2007, D'Souza decided to invest in growth. Meanwhile, rivals were cutting back.D'Souza told everyone at Cognizant to spend more time with customers and more effort in marketing to potential ones. Over the next few years, he traveled to meet many of them, showing that the company was committed top to bottom to making itself invaluable.Differentiating itself from tech outsourcing companies, Cognizant acquired consultancies and emphasized its long-term strategic advisory relationships.All For OneIn February 2012, D'Souza made a radical decision. The company was reorganized under three leaders to leave him free from day-to-day operational management to concentrate on future technology.With $3.36 billion in cash and short-term investments and no debt, Cognizant is placing its bet on balancing its core revenue sources with a gamble on potential ones.Headed by President Gordon Coburn and group CEOs Rajeev Mehta and Chandrasekaran Ramakrishnan, Cognizant's services are divided into three horizons:• 1. The cash cow of application development, maintenance and testing, enterprise resource planning, data warehousing and business intelligence.• 2. Fast-growing management consulting, IT infrastructure management and business process.• 3. New technologies and markets such as Latin America."D'Souza is risking both his own reputation and career," wrote Forbes India. "But as Albert Einstein once said: Problems cannot be solved by the same level of thinking that created them."D'Souza's lesson is that when things are going well, look for ways to break out to the next level."I've seen CEOs who are strong in leadership or management, but Frank is truly rare in having such outsized capabilities in both," said Malcolm Frank, executive vice president and chief strategist at Cognizant. "I've seen him build a galvanized sense of purpose across the entire company with a compelling long-term vision, then give us whiplash by immediately switching to work closely with a particular business unit, holding them to key metrics and deliverables in incredible detail."
Cisco Systems (CSCO) is transitioning more into services — and its services unit is in its own transition, adding its first consulting initiatives.
The No. 1 maker of networking gear continues to scramble to boost revenue from areas outside its core network routers and switches, where sales have been slowing.

As part of these efforts, Cisco is launching consulting initiatives within its services business, focusing on areas such as security and cloud computing. Services accounts for more than 20% of Cisco's revenue, but the unit's growth has slowed the past year.
In consulting, Cisco is targeting fast-growing areas such as data analytics, software-defined networking (SDN) and the "Internet of Things" trend of many types of machines connected to the Internet.
IBD recently discussed Cisco's services strategy with Edzard Overbeek, Cisco senior vice president.
IBD: Is Cisco's service business synonymous with systems integration?

Overbeek: It's different. We are introducing smart services. We build analytics to help run optimized and configured networks. About 10 years ago, we started to get more requests from customers to help design their networks. We built an advanced services group that's aligned with our data center architectures, networking equipment, etc.
IBD: How is the company expanding the service business ?

Overbeek: We are extending into areas (such as) application centric infrastructure, which is a new way for us to address SDN and basically help our customers solve their challenges around cloud, mobility, security and social (media).
IBD: What are the target areas for the new consulting services?

Overbeek: Our security service is one, which helps companies become even more secure using our technology, solutions, methods and processes. The security agenda is a big concern (of customers). In our cloud services, in some cases, we manage the networks for our customers. In our industry solutions unit, we are building industry templates that help customers in retail .
IBD: Why emphasize consulting?

Overbeek: Customers have questions about these new business opportunities. (With consulting) we can sit in front of them and help them define those from the problem statement to building solutions. That will help them become more agile, save costs and increase productivity.
IBD: Why launch these now?

Overbeek: The biggest transition is ahead of us (with things like) lighting systems, air conditioning systems, traffic management systems, smart grids — all of these networks are starting to open up and basically create a huge connection of potentially billions of devices that now will be moving toward a network fabric, and we believe we are at the core of that transition. If you want to build that, you need to offer different solutions and different insights in consulting.
IBD: How critical is the service business to Cisco?
Overbeek: It's always been very critical. And it will shift toward even more critical going forward.
IBD: How does Cisco compete with other service providers such as Accenture (ACN) and IBM (IBM)?

Overbeek: Of course we have a lot of competitors, but the services we are building are really around our networking and compute fabric. Accenture and IBM are big partners of our services into their customer base. ... We need partners to really get reach and depth and breadth in our solutions portfolio. We then build our full capability around services to address cloud, Big Data and analytics, social and security. We have a huge market position ahead of us.
IBD: Cisco's service revenue growth rate has slipped steadily the past five quarters. Why?

Overbeek: We have a slower product and technology sales cycle now. That has an implication on the services business. This is the reason we are implementing a strategy that uses all of (our) products and technology (but) also creates a more independent set of solutions.Cisco Systems (CSCO) is transitioning more into services — and its services unit is in its own transition, adding its first consulting initiatives.The No. 1 maker of networking gear continues to scramble to boost revenue from areas outside its core network routers and switches, where sales have been slowing.As part of these efforts, Cisco is launching consulting initiatives within its services business, focusing on areas such as security and cloud computing. Services accounts for more than 20% of Cisco's revenue, but the unit's growth has slowed the past year.In consulting, Cisco is targeting fast-growing areas such as data analytics, software-defined networking (SDN) and the "Internet of Things" trend of many types of machines connected to the Internet.IBD recently discussed Cisco's services strategy with Edzard Overbeek, Cisco senior vice president.IBD: Is Cisco's service business synonymous with systems integration?Overbeek: It's different. We are introducing smart services. We build analytics to help run optimized and configured networks. About 10 years ago, we started to get more requests from customers to help design their networks. We built an advanced services group that's aligned with our data center architectures, networking equipment, etc.IBD: How is the company expanding the service business ?Overbeek: We are extending into areas (such as) application centric infrastructure, which is a new way for us to address SDN and basically help our customers solve their challenges around cloud, mobility, security and social (media).IBD: What are the target areas for the new consulting services?Overbeek: Our security service is one, which helps companies become even more secure using our technology, solutions, methods and processes. The security agenda is a big concern (of customers). In our cloud services, in some cases, we manage the networks for our customers. In our industry solutions unit, we are building industry templates that help customers in retail .IBD: Why emphasize consulting?Overbeek: Customers have questions about these new business opportunities. (With consulting) we can sit in front of them and help them define those from the problem statement to building solutions. That will help them become more agile, save costs and increase productivity.IBD: Why launch these now?Overbeek: The biggest transition is ahead of us (with things like) lighting systems, air conditioning systems, traffic management systems, smart grids — all of these networks are starting to open up and basically create a huge connection of potentially billions of devices that now will be moving toward a network fabric, and we believe we are at the core of that transition. If you want to build that, you need to offer different solutions and different insights in consulting.IBD: How critical is the service business to Cisco?Overbeek: It's always been very critical. And it will shift toward even more critical going forward.IBD: How does Cisco compete with other service providers such as Accenture (ACN) and IBM (IBM)?Overbeek: Of course we have a lot of competitors, but the services we are building are really around our networking and compute fabric. Accenture and IBM are big partners of our services into their customer base. ... We need partners to really get reach and depth and breadth in our solutions portfolio. We then build our full capability around services to address cloud, Big Data and analytics, social and security. We have a huge market position ahead of us.IBD: Cisco's service revenue growth rate has slipped steadily the past five quarters. Why?Overbeek: We have a slower product and technology sales cycle now. That has an implication on the services business. This is the reason we are implementing a strategy that uses all of (our) products and technology (but) also creates a more independent set of solutions.

Accenture's  (ACN) immediate future could be a bit more challenging than recently thought. At least, that's the view of analysts who follow the global information technology services provider and consulting firm. On Tuesday, the consensus revenue expectation for Accenture's fiscal third quarter ended May 31 fell to $7.16 billion from the previous consensus of $7.19 billion, according to analysts…

Tech services provider Accenture late Thursday said consulting revenue missed its expectations, and its revenue and revenue guidance lagged Wall Street forecasts. The company's shares were down 6.5% in after-hours trading, after Accenture (ACN) released results for its fiscal Q3 ended May 31. Earnings per share edged views, however, and new bookings rose. "In management consulting, the macro environment continues…
Accenture (ACN) is continuing its comeback story.
The leading global IT services and consulting firm Thursday posted second-quarter results that beat views — a sign the firm is shrugging off macroeconomic concerns.
The company's sales forecast for the current quarter edged analyst estimates.
The results show Accenture can deliver even in a quarter known as seasonally weak, says UBS analyst Arvind Ramnani.

"Accenture continues to take market share as buyers of IT services continue to gravitate toward Accenture's brand and their industry-leading tech and consulting capabilities," he said. "Accenture has some of the best advisory capabilities in the IT services and that works in their favor."
For the second quarter ended Feb. 29, Accenture reported a per-share profit of 97 cents a share, up 29% from the year-ago period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 86 cents.
Revenue reached $6.8 billion, up 12% vs. a year ago. Analysts had expected $6.64 billion.
Shares closed Thursday at 63.52, down a fraction, and rose by more than 1% in after-hours trading.
For the current quarter, Accenture expects revenue of $7.05 billion to $7.25 billion. Analysts were targeting $7.03 billion. Its Q3 revenue last year was $6.7 billion.
Accenture is seeing growth in analytics, social media and cloud-based services.
Concerns over the recent recession appear to be waning, Accenture CEO Pierre Nanterme said during a conference call with analysts.

"In my recent conversations with the CEOs of our clients, it is clear that the marketplace forces driving the need for large-scale transformation are still here and in this context our growth strategy continues to be extremely relevant to our clients," he said.

Accenture has had six consecutive quarters of double-digit percentage sales growth. Much of that growth is in the wake of the post-recession economy, says Ali Zaidi, an analyst with research firm IDC.
"Right after the recession you saw very high growth because they did lose a lot of growth during the recession," he said.
In the quarter, Accenture's revenue from new bookings reached $7.94 billion, vs. $6.98 billion in the year-ago period.
Its customers include Fortune 500 companies and governments. Revenue comes from five operating groups.

Operational expenses are increasing. Accenture's Q2 operating expenses were $6.3 billion vs. $5.7 billion in the year-ago period and $6.6 billion in Q1. The biggest item is payroll, which will likely increase as it expands operations, says Josh Olson, an analyst for Edward Jones.

"Their ongoing challenge is seeking out, recruiting and training highly qualified individuals in these new markets around the world," he said.Accenture (ACN) is continuing its comeback story.The leading global IT services and consulting firm Thursday posted second-quarter results that beat views — a sign the firm is shrugging off macroeconomic concerns.The company's sales forecast for the current quarter edged analyst estimates.The results show Accenture can deliver even in a quarter known as seasonally weak, says UBS analyst Arvind Ramnani."Accenture continues to take market share as buyers of IT services continue to gravitate toward Accenture's brand and their industry-leading tech and consulting capabilities," he said.
